assetIdentification.assetDescription: Provides audio streaming and file playback capabilities for entertainment content

cybersecurityProperties.description: Ensures that media files and playback controls cannot be maliciously modified
cybersecurityProperties.protectionGoal: Prevent unauthorized modification of media content or control functions

cybersecurityProperties.description: Ensures that media playback functionality remains available for legitimate use
cybersecurityProperties.protectionGoal: Maintain entertainment functions during vehicle operation

cybersecurityProperties.description: Protects media content licenses and user playlists from unauthorized access
cybersecurityProperties.protectionGoal: Prevent unauthorized access to protected content and user preferences

threatScenarios.title: Audio Volume Manipulation Attack
threatScenarios.description: An attacker manipulates the audio volume control parameters via CAN bus or other interface to produce extreme volume levels that could startle the driver

initialAccess.method: Access to vehicle network via USB interface, Bluetooth vulnerability, or physical access to CAN bus
prerequisites: Knowledge of audio control message formats

steps.description: Gain access to the vehicle's communication network
steps.technique: Connect to USB port, exploit Bluetooth pairing vulnerability, or access OBD-II port
CAN bus sniffing or IVI API inspection

steps.description: Craft malicious audio volume control messages
steps.technique: Packet crafting with extreme parameter values

steps.description: Inject crafted messages into the audio control subsystem
steps.technique: CAN message injection or API call manipulation

unsafeControlActions: Audio volume set to maximum when not requested by driver
Audio volume changes rapidly without user input
controlFlaws: No validation of volume parameter ranges
No authentication of volume control commands
No rate limiting on volume change operations

attackFeasibility.justification: Requires proximity to the vehicle and specialized knowledge of the audio subsystem message formats, but once access is obtained, the manipulation itself is straightforward

relevantVulnerabilities.description: Improper input validation in IVI audio subsystem allows arbitrary volume manipulation
Missing authentication for audio control messages on CAN bus

existingControls.description: Basic hardware volume limiting circuit in amplifier
Software volume range checks in user interface

threatScenarios.title: Malicious Media File Execution
threatScenarios.description: An attacker crafts a specially formatted media file that exploits vulnerabilities in the media player's parsing code to execute arbitrary code when played

initialAccess.method: Delivery of malicious media file via USB drive, streaming service, or Bluetooth transfer
prerequisites: Ability to create malformed media files

steps.description: Identify vulnerabilities in media parsing libraries
steps.technique: Static code analysis, fuzzing, or vulnerability research

steps.description: Craft malicious media file exploiting identified vulnerabilities
steps.technique: File format manipulation or payload embedding

steps.description: Deliver malicious file to target vehicle
steps.technique: Physical USB delivery, compromised streaming service, or Bluetooth transfer

steps.description: Execute payload when file is played
steps.technique: Buffer overflow, heap spray, or format string exploitation

unsafeControlActions: Media player executes untrusted code from media files
Media player does not validate file format before processing
controlFlaws: Inadequate input validation for media files
Lack of memory protection in media processing
No sandboxing for media playback processes

attackFeasibility.justification: Requires sophisticated knowledge of media format vulnerabilities and user interaction to play the malicious file, but does not require special privileges once the file is created

relevantVulnerabilities.description: Buffer overflow in media codec allows arbitrary code execution
Integer overflow in MP3 parser leads to memory corruption

existingControls.description: Limited file format validation before playback
Memory management protections in operating system

threatScenarios.title: Media Subsystem Denial of Service
threatScenarios.description: An attacker causes the media playback system to crash or become unresponsive by exploiting resource management vulnerabilities

initialAccess.method: Introduction of specially crafted media files or streaming content
prerequisites: Basic knowledge of media file formats
Access to USB port or streaming capabilities

steps.description: Create or obtain resource-intensive media files
steps.technique: Generate extremely large or complex media files or metadata structures

steps.description: Deliver crafted files to the vehicle
steps.technique: USB drive, streaming service, or Bluetooth transfer

steps.description: Trigger resource exhaustion in media subsystem
steps.technique: Simultaneous playback requests or complex file parsing operations

steps.description: Maintain resource consumption to prevent recovery

unsafeControlActions: Media system consumes excessive CPU or memory resources
Media playback does not recover from resource exhaustion
controlFlaws: No resource usage limits for media playback
Inadequate error handling for malformed media files
No isolation between media processes and other IVI functions

attackFeasibility.justification: Creating files that exhaust system resources is relatively simple and requires minimal technical knowledge, though user interaction is needed to initiate playback

relevantVulnerabilities.description: Resource exhaustion vulnerability in media parser allows DoS
Inadequate timeout mechanism in streaming audio handler

existingControls.description: Basic watchdog timer for media processes
Media process restart capability after crash

relatedStandards.description: Systems Theoretic Process Analysis for Security

relatedRequirements.description: The media playback system shall validate all audio content before playback
relatedRequirements.cybersecurityGoal: Prevent malicious code execution through media files

relatedRequirements.description: The media playback system shall maintain audio volume within safe limits
relatedRequirements.cybersecurityGoal: Prevent audio manipulation that could distract the driver

relatedRequirements.description: The system shall sanitize all inputs from external media sources
relatedRequirements.cybersecurityGoal: Prevent code injection and buffer overflow attacks

relatedRequirements.description: The system shall implement resource quotas for media playback processes
relatedRequirements.cybersecurityGoal: Prevent denial of service through resource exhaustion

keyTerms.Buffer Overflow: Software vulnerability where a program writes data beyond the allocated memory buffer
keyTerms.Code Injection: Attack technique inserting malicious code through input fields
keyTerms.Fuzzing: Automated testing technique that provides invalid or random data as input

contentSummary: Threat scenarios for Media Playback System addressing three key threats: audio volume manipulation attacks (TS-MEDIA-01), malicious media file execution (TS-MEDIA-02), and media subsystem denial of service (TS-MEDIA-03). Each scenario details the attack vector, steps, control flaws per STPA methodology, and attack feasibility assessment using CVSS. Attack feasibility ratings are MEDIUM for all scenarios. Existing controls show insufficient protection, requiring additional security measures as identified in the complementary risk assessment document.
